text: Any change?
Hmm... well, let me see. She sarcastically holds the crying baby to her ear.
He’s still crying.
Well can’t you do something?
Can't you?
(menacing) I don’t think you’d like my idea. Suddenly the baby quiets, as if he understood the threat.
A-hem. The tigers look up. Sitting in a tree overhead is JEFFERS a chimpanzee.
Sorry to interrupt. I couldn’t help overhearing.
Funny how eavesdropping can lead to that. Jefferson climbs down and sits with them.
As a concerned fellow prisoner, I can’t help but point out the obvious.
Obvious what? @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055
You two were born in the wild. He’s first-generation captivity. Your instincts don’t apply here. Not behind bars.
Would you excuse us? This is a family matter.
But it’s also a larger, society matter.
What do you suggest we do?
Jefferson doesn’t have suggestions. Only complaints.
They're observations. Much needed observations, I might add. And I can’t possibly fix our situation alone. It will take the combined effort of all the animals to gain our freedom.
Ridiculous.

Can't you see? Being locked in these cages is robbing us of not just our dignity, but our very being. The fact that you can’t bond with your son is the perfect example -- The Father Tiger ROARS in anger, causing the baby to star crying again. Jefferson freezes in fear.
We’re not an example of anything - especially your political nonsense. Now leave us alone.
(to baby) There, there. Everything’s alright. Jefferson climbs back up the tree, still frightened, but truly sorry that he didn’t help. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055
Jefferson walking, concerned. Down from a nearby tree com ROSS, a fast-talking, female babboon.
Hey - how'd it go? Did you help? Did they listen? Are they going to join the fight for freedom?
Badly. No. No. And no.
Don’t give up. It’s a long fight. You said so yourself.
Thanks, Ross.
Can I help? How can I help? Jefferson perks up a bit, and stares ahead with convictio
Rally in the square. Ross’ face lights up.
You mean it?
You bet I do. He walks ahead. Still smiling, she heads the other way.
Ross passes a RHINO, a GAZELLE and a FLAMINGO hanging out a closed-up souvenir cart. Without stopping, she tells th
Rally in the square. They roll their eyes, but after a moment, they follow her MONTAGE: Ross spreading the word to several different ani that there’s going to be a:
Rally in the square. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055 They all react with the same annoyed boredom, but comply
A sectioned-off, mini ampitheater used for kids’ shows. As thirty or so animals lazily file in, Ross directs the seating as if handling a riot.

Okay, easy does it. No shoving. There’s plenty of room for everyone. Smaller animals down to the front. Larger folks to the back, please. Working with Ross is FRANKLIN, a slacker, teenage spider monkey. He mimics Ross, pointing animals in whatever direction she has already established for them. When a pair of bats appear at the entrance, Ross immediat pays special attention to them.

(to bats) Right this way, sir. Miss. -- or is it Mrs.? Ms. probably. You look like a Ms. (to others) Excuse us. Visually challenged guests coming through. Make way, please. (to bats) You’1l be down in front here. (to others) Excuse us. Pardon us. Make way for the visually challenged. Unable to get by the rhino, Ross snaps at him.
Hey, a little respect here, huh? When everyone is in place, Jefferson ascends the stage. H has pages of notes in his hand and seems confident -- -- Until he looks out at the moderately-sized crowd.
Umm... uuhhh... tonight (gulp) I just wanted to, um.... @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  The crowd groans. They saw this coming. Jefferson starts sweating.
No, wait. I just. it’s just... what we need is ...um, ...
From the side, Ross desperately roots for him, trying to him the courage to succeed. Franklin stands beside her, m confused than anything.
There’s this .... um... You see... (defeated) Sorry. Thanks for coming. Jefferson slinks off the stage and sits on a nearby bench The animals file out shaking their heads. CLOSE ON: The Rhino.
(sarcastic) Gee, didn’t see that coming. CLOSE ON: two GIRAFFES filing out.
Tell me again why we do this.
Because if we don’t come as a group, he’ll come to each of our cages and talk for hours. Ross runs to Jefferson who sits quietly staring ahead. Franklin follows close behind her.
You did good! That was real... progress, I thought. (to Franklin) Didn't he do good, Franklin?
Kinda the same as last time. And the time before that. And the -- Ross smacks the back of his head with her tail.
(to Jefferson) It’s not your fault. It’s a disorder called groupatalkaphobia. (MORE )
@Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  ROSS (cont'd) Instead of blaming the victim, we, as a society, should get you the help you need. She holds his shoulders.
We will get through this, and everyone will join the cause. Franklin looks around their setting.
You think everyone would fit in here? Jefferson starts to hyperventilate at the thought.
Nice going. Quick! Get a paper bag! Franklin darts off. Jefferson is trying to say something.

It’s going to be fine. You don’t need him. I’m here. It’s okay. Franklin returns with a popcorn bag. Ross gives it to Jefferson, who sucks air from it and starts CHOKING. Ross pulls the bag away and POPCORN FLIES everywhere. She glares at Franklin.

An empty bag, you nitwit! Ross does the Heimlich on Jefferson by wrapping her tail around his waist and grabbing it with one hand. It works. Jefferson coughs up popcorn kernels and breathe again. But his eyes stay staring ahead, almost catatonic.
Why don’t we just find his brother?
Because no one knows where he is.
Don’t you think that’s weird? Disappearing for two hours every night. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055
Yes. But that’s Lincoln. He’s weird. We’1ll just have to wait for him to come back from ... wherever.
Just like last time...

Quiet and dark. FRANKLIN (CONT’D - O.S.) -.. and the time before that. And the time before that. We track along a perimeter fence. SUSPENSEFUL MUSIC slowl builds as we approach an unknown building and track INTO exhaust vent in the exterior wall. INT. AIR VENTS —- CONTINUOUS Continuing track as music builds. Faint voices can be hea in the distance, coming from somewhere in the building an traveling through the vents. Their volume steadily increa
You'll never get away with this.

We'll see about that. We hear the rumbling of a fight as we turn a corner. A spooky blue glow flickers throughout this 15-feet of ai vent. The light comes from a grate at the end of the tunn Sitting in front of the grate, his back to us, is another chimp, Jefferson’s brother LINCOLN. TRACK IN over Lincoln’s shoulder and we see what he sees:

The only light in the room comes from a 20-inch TV in one corner. A lazy, film-geek GUARD (early 20s) sits in the d chair, intently watching a 1970s cop movie. He is unaware of Lincoln, who is also transfixed by the f
@Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055 The two men have finished their fight. The Bad Guy has t Good Guy pinned to a wall.
The police know about your scheme. They’re on their way right now.
I got news for you... CLOSE ON: Lincoln, watching.
«+. the police work for me. Lincoln’s eyes go wide, surprised by the revelation. BAD GUY (CONT’D) And your friends won't be bothering me any more. I’ve seen to that.
You .... animal! Taken from the moment, Lincoln rolls his eyes with a “yea yeah” look, then reacts in inspired awe as we HEAR the Go Guy escape and the forces of good take over.
No!! Ahhhgggghhh!!!
That’1l teach you to operate on the wrong side of the law.
Still on a satisfied Lincoln, we hear theme music and see scrolling credits reflected in his still-focused eyes.
Ross tries to console a still anxiety-ridden Jefferson wh Franklin tosses a rock in the air and tries unsuccessfull bat it with a stick. Lincoln approaches the trio.
Hi guys. What’s up? @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055
We had another rally.
How'd it go?
Same as last time... and the --
Alright!
Thanks for watching him. I’1l take it from here. Ross reluctantly makes room for Lincoln, who puts his arm around Jefferson, who is visibly calmer with Lincoln ther
Good night, Jefferson. See you tomorrow. Jefferson just nods as he and Lincoln walk off.
Lincoln and Jefferson walking. Jefferson is a bit calmer.
It’s just nerves. Public speaking just isn’t your thing.
How can I be a political leader if I can’t face a bunch of friends in a familiar place?
I’m not sure a political leader is what’s needed here.
That's because you’re oblivious to the oppression. They get to their cage. Lincoln takes a key from under a “hide-a-key” fake rock and unlocks the door. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  10.
No one takes me seriously.
That’s because you take yourself too seriously. Did you ever think of that?
We have an obligation to the animals who aren’t as smart as we are.
An obligation to do what?
To better our situation. You want to spend the rest of your life in this cage? We’re prisoners! And everyone is too blind to see it.
No one is blind -- (to himself) Well, except the bats. (back to Jefferson) Look. We’re here. We’re fed. We’re taken care of. We have doctors, for crying out loud. Kids love us.
Their kids.
There’s nothing we can do about it. All your activism. Do you really think you can achieve equal rights for zoo animals?
See how they brainwash you? There shouldn't be any such thing as a zoo animal. We’re just animals. They're responsible for the zoo part.
So we should -- what?
Unite! Rise up! Take our freedom back! @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  11.
That’s impossible.
Nothing’s impossible.
You can’t win.
So you should only fight if you know you can win?
Ummm...Kinda - yeah.
That’s some life philosophy. Remind me to write that down sometime so I‘1ll never forget it. Disappointed, Jefferson slinks off to a dark corner.
Jefferson, I --
-- good night. Lincoln sighs, knowing this talk is over - for tonight.

A beautiful, sunny day. Throngs of people enter the gates Kids run ahead of bag-holding, stroller-pushing parents. Looking out of place in this crowd is ETHAN LATTE. A pale thin artist-poser-type, Ethan is bald, has a goatee and i dressed all in black: turtleneck, sunglasses and blazer - even though it’s obviously hot out. Ethan talks on a cell phone as he walks.

That’s not going to happen. We’re shooting the scene just as I wrote it. Tell them that Ethan Latte doesn’t compromise his art for anything. -- Look, I’m in the middle of something here. Kind of a blind date. Never mind where. I’1l call you back. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  12. He flips his phone closed. As the crowd disperses in different directions, we see that Ethan is with an attrac single MOM in her thirties and her 7-year-old DAUGHTER. The daughter runs ahead. Ethan does little to hide his disdain for this outing.
All set?
Yes, let’s ... zoo.
Sorry again about the mix-up. She really is supposed to be with her father today. It’s really nice of you to come along. Ethan takes out a DV camera and checks the gauges.
Uh-huh. While looking through the lens to test light, Ethan steps something, soiling his expensive, trendy shoes. The leather shoes have distinctive ORANGE TIPS.
(to himself) Wonderful.
Ethan and the Mom approach the daughter, who hangs on the fence, trying to engage the chimps.
My sister says you make movies. That’s interes--.
-- Films. I make films. Movies have clichés and car chases. Lincoln hears this exchange, perks up and comes down to s closer to them.
I see. And what do your films have? @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  13.
Meaningful stories. Strong, conflicted characters. Redeeming social commentary. See the difference?
Uh ... sure. She is annoyed at his arrogance, but tries to make the be of it, for her daughter’s sake.
I used to see lots of movies. All kids’ stuff these days, though.
Mmm-hmm. I have a film selected in the Moonsong Film Festival. The mom rolls her eyes and sips from a water bottle. Linc listens intently.
That’s nice. Is that like a contest or something? Ethan lets out a condescending laugh.

It’s only the biggest independent film showcase in the world. You get recognized there and you can write your own ticket in Hollywood, baby. In the middle of another water sip, she nearly chokes on Ethan's “baby.” She’s about to lean into him when:
Look, mom! He likes me! The daughter is up on the monkey cage railing, leaning ov
Honey, don’t climb on that. She scurries ahead and helps her daughter down.
(whispers) That Ethan guy is weird. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  14.

That’s actually one of his better qualities. She turns back to Ethan, who is again talking on his cell phone, and checking himself out in the glass reflection o another section of the monkey area. Lincoln comes up to the glass and mimics an oblivious Eth The mom and daughter laugh. Ethan hangs up.
Can you get a shot of us?
A ... shot?
Yeah. Take some video of us in front of the monkeys.
What would be the point of that?
To remember what great fun we had at the zoo. Ethan sighs, checks his camera, the sunlight, and. .
Ethan has set up an elaborate shoot, with barriers to hol patrons back - until he cues them to walk past as extras. Lincoln watches, riveted. The mom and daughter are MORTIF as Ethan calls to them:
Again! .... and action! The mom and daughter smile awkwardly and wave at the came
Don’t wave! ... Define the moment! Share the moment! Be the moment ... Don’t react! Act!
During the shooting, Lincoln holds his fingers up and fra the mom and daughter. His composition is better than Etha @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  15.
(groans) Cut! Must you be so stiff?
Okay, look, we should really be getting home.
I was only trying to say something with the film.
You said plenty. Thanks. It’s been areal... treat. I’1l be sure to thank my sister for setting us up. She takes her daughter’s hand. As they walk away, the daughter looks back.
Bye - freak! Ethan erases the footage and turns to leave, but realizes has no idea which way the exit is.

Tired and sweating, Ethan is still trying to find the exi He sits on a bench, puts his camera down and tries to mak cell phone call. No reception. Frustrated, he gets up quickly, knocking his camera into crocodile pit. It lands, intact, in a bush. MIKEY, the crocodile immediately eyes it. Ethan starts to climb in. MIKEY moves, and Ethan thinks better of it and calls out.
Excuse me! A little help here! I need to speak with a zoo employee. A small crowd gathers around the yelling Ethan.
Lincoln is relaxing in a hammock when BRAD, a free-flying bird lands nearby. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  16.
What’s all the commotion over there? Did Mikey eat someone?
Nah. Some guy dropped his video camera in the pit.
(perks ) Really?
Yeah. No big --

-- Get to Mikey. Quick! Tell him -- Suddenly, a family is at Lincoln's cage, peering in, so h slyly whispers something to Brad, who shrugs and flies of Now watched by the family, Lincoln scratches himself and swings on the hammock.
Ethan with a portly ZOOKEEPER who takes his job very seriously, gesturing dramatically with his hands as he sp
Can’t you just climb down there? Isn't that your job?!
Not exactly, sir. But we can lure the croc back inside - there - to create a safe path - here - from which we can retrieve your personal belonging.
How long will that take?

Well, croc manipulation is by no Means an exact science, but I can assure you we will do our best to retrieve your personal belonging. Brad lands on Mikey’s head and whispers something to him. croc looks puzzled at him. Brad just shrugs. Suddenly, the croc moves for the camera. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  17.
He’s moving! He’s going to it! Do something!
He’s just exhibiting instinctive behavior. Crocs are naturally very curious. An often overlooked fact about the giant reptile.
He’s going to eat it!
(chuckles ) Oh, I doubt that, sir. He’s not like a shark. If it’s not food or food-smelling, he’1ll just -- Suddenly the croc opens its jaws and eats the camera.
-- well, hoo-dee-dumpkin. There's somethin’ you don’t see every day. Ethan doesn’t know whether to lash out or weep.
Your filthy, wretched zoo is going to pay for that.
I'm afraid the zoo is not responsible for personal belongings lost, stolen or damaged during your visit. Your admittance ticket is also a contract --
Oh, shut up! He storms off, but not necessarily in the right direction he stops and turns back.
How do I get out of here!?
Oh that’s easy. Down to the giraffes, turn right, through the tunnel and around the flamingo garden. If ya see hippos, you've gone too far! @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  18.
How utterly....easy!
Enjoy the rest of your stay, sir. Ethan storms off. Mikey sits motionless in his pit
Mikey still motionless. He hasn’t moved.
Bravo. Lincoln climbs down next to Mikey and holds out his hand.
Let’s have it. Mikey opens his jaws, revealing the camera, perfectly int Lincoln reaches, but Mikey CLAMPS shut. Lincoln pulls his hand away just in time.
Was that supposed to be funny? Mikey’s talk is dumb-sounding with the camera in his mout
What’s in it for me?
Nothing.
Well that’s not good enough. Lincoln sighs and looks around. He expected this to be a short visit.
What would you like?
I don’t know. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  19.
Haven't you had quite a bit of time to think about it?
I guess.
How about some food?
Okay.
Okay. You give me the camera, and I'll see to it that that rock over there has food on it first thing in the morning.
Stuff I like?

Absolutely. Right by that little door over there. How’s eight o'clock? Mikey thinks about it and finally sticks his tongue out, camera sitting on it. Lincoln takes the slimy camera and wipes it off as best he can.
Lincoln is testing the camera, learning its features, whe Jefferson comes in.
And just what do you plan on doing with that?
Make a movie, write my own ticket to Hollywood and get recognized at the Moonsong Film Festival.
What? The Moon-who what festival? Lincoln imitates Ethan, but just to amuse himself.
It’s only the biggest independent film showcase in the world, baby. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  20.
When are you going to stop playing and get serious? Lincoln points the camera at his brother.
Who's playing? C’mon, pout - oh, you're already pouting.
Very funny.
Okay, funny. Funny is good. If only we had a banana peel. Jefferson laughs. Lincoln is stunned.
Was that a laugh?
No.
Yes it was. I have it on tape.
It wasn’t on.
But I saw it. ... It’s not a crime, you know. Laughing.
I know.
(joking) But don’t let me see it again! This is serious business! I am an arteest!
And I'm going to bed. He goes to his corner.
Fine, be that way. But you’ll never work in this town again!
What? @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  21.
Never mind. Good night. Lincoln fiddles some more with the camera.
A long line of animals waits to get in. EXT. ZOO SQUARE STAGE —- CONTINUOUS Lincoln points the camera at us, looking out from one sid
Okay, this is called a screen test. Opposite him is a FLAMINGO holding a sheet of paper.
You want us to talk?
Yeah.
And humans are gonna see this?

It’s okay. Animals talk in movies all the time. Just read the lines. The important thing is to relax and have fun. He looks back into the camera. The flamingo opens his mou to speak and Lincoln cuts him off:

And remember - you just discovered you have a horrible disease and that your children are actually aliens from outer space. The flamingo’s face goes blank. He looks down at the page then back up at Lincoln.
Whenever you’re ready... The flamingo can only manage a GULP and a GRUNT.
@Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  22. We see various zoo animals through Lincoln's camera frame A male rhino:
(deadpan ) You'll never take me alive, coppers.
Good. Try it again, a little tougher. You’re mean. Everyone’s afraid of you.
(identical deadpan) You'll never take me alive, coppers. A female gazelle:
I know you don’t lose me anymore.
Love.
What?
You don’t love me anymore.
I never loved you. We’re not even the same species-- That’s disgust-- oh! The line. Sorry. I get it. A male OTTER stands silent for a beat, then suddenly look scared and points to the sky:
Look out!!!! Lincoln looks up from his camera, and checks his script.
That was good, but the line is -- BONK! Lincoln gets hit on the head with a falling pine co @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  23.
The tests are done. Lincoln starts packing up and sees Ro watching curiously. She’s conflicted throughout the scene
Oh, hey Ross. Didn’t see you there. C’mon down. Thanks for waiting.
(dreamy ) Me? (catches herself) Oh, no. I’m not here to be part of this movie thing. She moves in closer to Lincoln, unable to hide her fascination with the camera.
No?
I’m here to scold you. Playing with human people toys when they lock -- (points) What does that do?
It zooms the picture closer. Wanna see?
Of course not! -- okay. Lincoln smiles and lets her try the camera. As she looks through, Ross reaches in front of the camera, trying to t whatever is obviously zoomed in close in her view.
You were scolding .. .?
(still looking) Huh? Right. People toys.
You don’t have to impress my brother. He likes you. Ross looks up from the camera. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  24.
That has nothing to do with -- did he say something? What did he say?
He doesn’t have to say anything to me. I know. (beat) I also know he wouldn’t mind if you were in the movie.
Really? I don’t know. That would be kinda -- okay! -- No, I couldn’t. He'd be mad. . . wouldn’t he?
Yeah, probably. (beat) But what if you weren’t actually in the movie? Ross pretends to get it, nodding.
Aaahhhhhh -- (gives up) What do you mean?

A compelling aerial shot moves down and tracks left aroun corner of the building as a scared-looking LEOPARD runs b top speed. Some moments later, as the dust settles, an exhausted OSTRICH runs by in pursuit.
Lincoln sitting high on the neck of Ben, the giraffe. The camera is fastened to Ben’s head and his neck is bent low turned, having provided the shot we just saw.
Cut! That was great! The giraffe slowly straightens his neck, lifting Lincoln above the crowd. He looks down to the ostrich.
How did that feel? Was that alright? @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055
(winded) I just don’t think anyone will believe that I could catch him. Murmurs of agreement from the animals.
They only have to believe that you want to catch him. Inspired, admiring approvals resonate. Lincoln is revered
Alright everyone. That’s it for tonight. Remember, eight-o’clock tomorrow night. We’1ll be... where are we tomorrow? He turns to Ross, who wears a cap and holds
Gift shop.
a clipboard. Gift shop. Eight o’clock. Get some rest, everyone. Great job tonight. The giraffe puts Lincoln down next to Ross.
You sure you wanna rip?
Huh?
Stop filming for the night.
Oh, wrap. It’s wrap. Yeah, I gota «+. thing I gotta do.
Oh, your ... nightly ... thing.
Yeah, the thing. I'll see ya tomorrow. Lincoln starts off. @Michaal Maltin / wea #1109055  26.
Alright then, have fun -- I mean, if it’s a fun thing. Lincoln waves without turning around.
Lincoln is walking with his camera, elated. He passes a quiet, dark cage and stops. He thinks a moment and goes b
Lincoln enters. No one seems to be around, but he suddenl hears a menacing GRUNT from a dark corner. Looking closer Lincoln sees the glowing eyes of WASHINGTON, a huge, intimidating gorilla.
Washington? The gorilla GRUNTS again in the darkness.
Hi. Sorry to disturb you.
Then why did you?
I'm making a movie, and I need a big tough guy. So I was wonder-- Washington suddenly ROARS and CHARGES at Lincoln, who dro the camera in fear and jumps up a tree.
Yeeez, man. What’s that all about? We’re on the same team here.
No we’re not. Get out of here!
I gotta get my camera. Can I get it without you hurting me?
I don’t know. Can you? Washington picks up the camera, looks at it, then suddenl holds it up high as if he will smash it on the ground. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  27.

Don’t! It’s not mine! It’s borrowed. C’mon. Gimme a break. You don't want to do it, fine. A lot of others do, though. You’ll be ruining it for everyone. Washington puts the camera down, growling some more, then moves back to his dark-corner spot. Lincoln climbs down, picks up the camera and scoots quick to safety. Before leaving, he calls back in:
What’s with you, anyway? Silence. Lincoln shakes his head and leaves.
Lincoln walks on and suddenly Jefferson is in his face.
Funny thing happened on the way to the rally.
Huh?
Nobody showed up. It was me in front of a crowd of zero.
There’s an easy joke there, but I’m not going to say it.
Your little movie nonsense with this toy of our captors is setting back the cause. Lincoln is angered by his brother’s selfishness.
Oh, here we go again. The cause. Freedom for all. So we can walk out into the street and get hit by a bus.
Getting out of this prison is the only thing that matters. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  28.
-- to you.
You're not helping.
And you're just jealous because everyone’s more interested in doing what I want them to do.
They don’t know any better.
And you do?
Yes! Movies are pointless.
You've never even seen one. Movies have a ... power. They can make you laugh, cry, and think in all kinds of new, exciting ways. They can ... they can change the world.
Have you been eating bugs off the orangutans again?
That was one time.
How can you honestly think all that make-believe nonsense could possibly matter?
They're stories. Everyone has one.
They're a waste of time. Lincoln thinks. Eureka.
Prove it.
What? @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  29.
Waste some time with me. Right now.
What? Where? -- (realizes) Is that where you -- ? Figures.
Come with me. ... C’mon.
Alright, fine. But only to show you just how stupid movies are.
Just give it a fair chance.
Yeah, yeah. They head off together, Lincoln leading the way.
Lincoln’s movie-watching spot is far more cramped now tha he’s sharing it. Jefferson fidgets mercilessly. The security office below is empty and dark, except for a small desk lamp.
How can you sit here every night? Where are we? Suddenly the office door opens.
Shhhhhh.

(whispers) This is stupid already. Lincoln puts a finger to his lips. He’s serious. The Guard takes a DVD from its case and ceremoniously put in the player. He adeptly works the remote through menus and starts the film. Onscreen we see an office building with a MEGAMULAC sign on top. A narrator speaks in voice-over: @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  30.
What you about to see is true. The people involved are not actors. Lincoln sighs in disappointment, but Jefferson is intrigu
Ten years ago, nine employees of Megamulacorp lost their life savings while company executives got rich. Onscreen image cuts to a group of sad-looking people.
These employees fought the system, beat the odds and won their justice. This is their story. Lincoln shakes his head and leans to Jefferson.
(whispers) This is a documentary. They’re boring. We can come back another ni--
Shhhhhh. Lincoln suddenly realizes - of course - this is exactly t kind of movie Jefferson would be into. And into it he is. Riveted. Lincoln tries again to watch.
Worked there all my life. Thought I could trust ‘em. Guess I was wrong. Bored already, Lincoln's eyes wander. He starts inspectin and biting his nails.

Jefferson in the same spot, watching. Lincoln lies next t him, fast asleep, drool hanging from his open mouth. As the credits roll, the guard leaves the office. Jeffers discovers the sleeping Lincoln and shakes him.
Huh? What? Who? I’m ready. -- Oh it’s over...So, what did you think? @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  31. Jefferson has a determined, inspired look.
Where’s that camera? He starts away down the vent.
Ha. You see? I told you. Movies can -- wait, my camera? Lincoln follows.
Why do you want my camera?
The chimps draw their usual crowd. Lincoln and Jefferson in a hammock, concealed by tree foliage. They speak softl mask their conversation from the watchful humans.
I don’t know. Documentaries are so boring.
We finally have a chance to tell our story. Really tell it.
I was telling a story.
About what?
An unlikely hero who saves the world.
From ... what?
(duh) The bad guys.
Okay. And your hero is...?
(proudly ) Featherman! (MORE )
@Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  32. LINCOLN (cont'd) (reluctant) Stuart.
The ostrich? A superhero?
Featherman actually has no super powers. He’s just highly trained --
-- Stuart?
He’s the best actor I could find. He does this thing with his eyebrows. (imitates) It’s really freaky.
In a documentary, no one would have to act. We’d all be ourselves.
What about all the work we’ve done? Jefferson fishes for an adequate answer. A-ha!
